text: SARAH LENTI: Nice and strong.

I just still can't
believe it happened.

I mean, I wanted it to happen
with every part of my being.

But it's just, you

and you're like no,
this is what I want.
I want a family.

I think back, and they're
just complete little miracles.
And they're a gift.

Well, I journaled on the
morning that I was 30

that if I was 38 and
single, I saw where

life was headed,
that I was going
to think about adoption or IVF.

I didn't know, but it was
almost a promise to myself.

It was the year that I was 39
that I actually got pregnant.

Christmas Eve I went
home and told my parents

about what I was
going to do, and they
were less than thrilled.

We grew up in a Christian
conservative home,

and they had very huge
concerns regarding

bringing a child into the
world without a father.

I had seven perfect
embryos, and so I
asked them to implant three.

And he argued with
me and challenged me.

And said, what are you going
to do if you end up with three?

I said, I'm not going to
get pregnant with one.

He said, oh, you're
going to get pregnant.
He said, they look too good.

And so he said,
tell me, why two?

And I said, if they're not
going to have a father, at least
they'll have each other.
They were born 10 weeks early.

They were in the NICU
for 2 and 1/2 months.

And I'd go every
morning at 9 o'clock
and leave every night at 9:30.

And I brought my computer
with me, and when they slept
I worked.

And when I was able to
hold them, I held them.
